newsitem.title: USA: FUND VIEW - Dreyfus Third Century.
newsitem.headline: FUND VIEW - Dreyfus Third Century.

text.p: The nearly 40 so-called "socially responsible" mutual funds in the United States often operate under a different set of pressures.
Before a fund buys a stock, it must pass muster with a set of "socially responsible" criteria as well as the traditional investment requirements.
Who prevails when the "socially responsible" criteria conflict with the investment issues? When push comes to shove
at the 25-year-old Dreyfus Third Century, its managers said, the socially responsible element prevails.

"If there is ever a question concerning a (socially conscious) problem with a company, and I feel that it would preclude their inclusion in the fund, then I would make that decision," said Eric Steedman, the co-portfolio manager who oversees research in social issues.

Steedman said at a recent briefing for reporters that the fund uses four criteria to measure social responsibility: Environmental performance, worker health and safety, and diversity, such as whether a company's senior management and the board of directors includes minorities and women.
The fourth criteria is consumer protection and product "purity," a standard under which the company avoids investments in companies whose products and services are harmful to consumers.
Based on these yardsticks, THE fund has not invested in tobacco, alcohol, gaming and most defense stocks.
Steedman and and co-manager Stephon Jackson said they generally find energy equities and stocks in the smokestack industry troublesome due to environmental issues.
The fund considers "socially responsible" issues after it weighs the financial fundamentals. Jackson said the fund seeks companies that offer "growth at a reasonable price."

Jackson seeks stocks with reasonable price/earnings, that have superior earnings growth compared to the rest of the sector, and has surprised Wall Street with its earnings estimates. It employs the usual method of talking to management.
After Jackson selects a stock, he confers with Steedman to see if the stock can pass the other set of requirements.
Jackson and Steedman acknowledge that the fund can't be all things to all "socially-responsible" investors, and won't adopt every social issue.

But the managers said they won't hesitate to unload what they considered a badly behaving stock. The fund sold shares of Briggs & Stratton Corp after the company sued the National Catholic Reporter for libel. The U.S. publication had criticized the company over its layoff practices.
The $580 million fund currently has 59 holdings, with most issues comprising about 3.5 percent of the portfolio.
Top holdings include Intel Corp, Microsoft Corp, Citicorp, BankAmerica Corp, Fannie Mae, Johnson and Johnson, and Merck and Co Inc.
The fund has returned 5.1 percent year to date through February 6, 24.33 percent in all of 1996, and 10.89 percent annualized over the last five years, according to Lipper.
